CatDescriptText: Owen Richardson, shopwright, Uptown and William Turner, steelworker, Uptown, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 3, 1960, pg. A1 with question "What is our country's most pressing domestic problem?"  Mr. Richardson's answer reads: "There are two or three pressing problems in our country.  Perhaps the main one concerns fair employment making certain that Negroes have the same job opportunities and the same chance for job advancements as others."  Mr.Turner's answer reads: "We have to do something down South, because the people there have not learned to accept integration.  They must accept the fact that we're all human beings."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Owen Richardson wearing light colored cap with embroidered fish, and light colored t-shirt, standing in front of store; Portrait of William Turner wearing straw hat with patterned band and sunglasses, posed in front of downspout on building
